messages.text: It's good that JuliaCon 2021 organizers are proactive and responsible so they decided to make next JuliaCon online already ... But I was looking forward to my first live JuliaCon and finally meet fellow julians in real life.

elements.text: It's good that JuliaCon 2021 organizers are proactive and responsible so they decided to make next JuliaCon online already ... But I was looking forward to my first live JuliaCon and finally meet fellow julians in real life.

messages.text: Yeah, we would have liked to go back to a physical conference, but it honestly seems quite uncertain for next summer. We can't really put on a conference in July if we wait to make a decision till may.

elements.text: Yeah, we would have liked to go back to a physical conference, but it honestly seems quite uncertain for next summer. We can't really put on a conference in July if we wait to make a decision till may.

messages.text: What I really missed in the virtual format was any kind of real audience. I thought people would give sort of like zoom talks and you could ask questions after, but instead it was like a chain of YouTube videos being made available and the discord threads seemed messy and couldn't keep up with the pace. I hope that this can be different next time around, but I guess there were good reasons for choosing that format

elements.text: What I really missed in the virtual format was any kind of real audience. I thought people would give sort of like zoom talks and you could ask questions after, but instead it was like a chain of YouTube videos being made available and the discord threads seemed messy and couldn't keep up with the pace. I hope that this can be different next time around, but I guess there were good reasons for choosing that format

messages.text: I participated in a really nice virtual conference not so long ago which had a format about which I was super skeptical beforehand but it turned out to be awesome: all speakers were asked to pre-record their talks (fitting in their allotted time) and upload them at the latest a some time before the conference (optionally including additional materials such as slides etc.). Then all materials were made available to participants a few days before the conference. The conference itself then was organized into 25 (?) minute slots; each slot had two talks assigned; the idea being that you watch the talk *before* and then the slot is basically a Q&A session, with roughly half the time dedicated to each of the two talks (but the format meant that was flexibility if one talk generated more interest than the other). So it's kinda "inverted classroom" but applied to talks. As I said, I was skeptical and expected a lot of awkward silence, and chair persons having to come up with questions etc., but it turned out that people had tons of questions and the slots were actually too short because of that.

before

and then the slot is basically a Q&A session, with roughly half the time dedicated to each of the two talks (but the format meant that was flexibility if one talk generated more interest than the other). messages.text: I wonder if there could be some way of arranging Q & A sessions to be held after each recorded talk is dropped.

messages.text: How rusty I am with design patterns in languages outside of julia because multidispatch is so elegant and friendly.

elements.text: How rusty I am with design patterns in languages outside of julia because multidispatch is so elegant and friendly.

messages.text: True.  Julia has totally ruined me for other languages that don’t support multiple dispatch and a powerful type system.

elements.text: True.  Julia has totally ruined me for other languages that don’t support multiple dispatch and a powerful type system.

messages.text: So how do we get <@U687RKK0E> to fix the systems programming language problem? Do we need to kick up an illegal cloning lab? Because every year I stay in Julia it makes it harder and harder to switch out for other projects :joy:.

Like... just scroll down on this page until you hit the Julia example... <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_dispatch#C#>
How can people not see how beautiful that is and how that should be everywhere.

messages.text: My code ran in ~2 seconds. I refactored and restarted. Suddenly it ran in 50 seconds. (Or, rather, not suddenly.) Why? It turns out that I had introduced a non-`const`  global that was used absolutely everywhere. `const` ing it put it back to 2 seconds

const
global that was used absolutely everywhere.
const
ing it put it back to 2 seconds

messages.text:
Julia 1.0.5 allocates less on linux than on Mac or Windows.
Appreciation: less allocations is unquestionably good
Gripe: :wat-duck:  why. This makes testing against regressions on allocations for high performance code much harder.

messages.text:
It’s scary how good the AI used by sites such as Flipboard must be getting: it recommended to me a tweet by <@U681ELA87> from about 11 minutes ago, about an improvement he’s made to JSON3 :slightly_smiling_face:.
Appreciation (as I’ve noted many times) for all those packages such as JSON3, CSV, etc.
Gripe, to social media’s seemingly knowing *everything* about what I like!

messages.text:
:star:: JET.jl is amazing. It's static analysis for Julia! :D And it also works in practice!
:grapes: : As soon as I apply it to anything I write, it turns out possible type errors in Base and various lower-level packages I use. That's not a problem with JET, but... it's like opening a Pandora's box of issues in Base and everywhere else.

elements.text: : JET.jl is amazing. It's static analysis for Julia! :D And it also works in practice!

: As soon as I apply it to anything I write, it turns out possible type errors in Base and various lower-level packages I use. That's not a problem with JET, but... it's like opening a Pandora's box of issues in Base and everywhere else.

messages.text:
Actually folks like <@UC8821DPY> have already done lots of great work to improve type stabilities in `Base` in terms of preventing invalidations :slightly_smiling_face: But yes, more improvements will be very appreciated for JET to be more practical.
We can also just improve Julia compiler; the more we improve Julia compiler, the more practical JET will be. E.g. some of the issues you may have faced will be fixed w/ this PR: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/38905>

messages.text:
The project I am working on has around 250 dependencies.
It’s great because standing on shoulders of giants to do pretty solidly advanced things, in comparatively few lines.
But precompilation in 1.5 takes like 10 minutes.
1.6 is so sweet
(but 1.6 is currently too broken for me to use for this, I was trying before and … not OK)

messages.text:
DataFrames.jl is pretty awesome, but I think most people would find this is confusing.
```julia> using DataFrames
julia> a = DataFrame(:a => [1,2,3], :b => [1,1,1])
3×2 DataFrame
│ Row │ a     │ b     │
│     │ Int64 │ Int64 │
├─────┼───────┼───────┤
│ 1   │ 1     │ 1     │
│ 2   │ 2     │ 1     │
│ 3   │ 3     │ 1     │
julia> sum(eachcol(a))
3-element Array{Int64,1}:
 2
 3
 4```
then find this a little upsetting
```julia> sum(eachrow(a))
ERROR:```

elements.text: DataFrames.jl is pretty awesome, but I think most people would find this is confusing.

julia> using DataFrames
julia> a = DataFrame(:a => [1,2,3], :b => [1,1,1])
3×2 DataFrame
│ Row │ a     │ b     │
│     │ Int64 │ Int64 │
├─────┼───────┼───────┤
│ 1   │ 1     │ 1     │
│ 2   │ 2     │ 1     │
│ 3   │ 3     │ 1     │
julia> sum(eachcol(a))
3-element Array{Int64,1}:
 2
 3
 4
then find this a little upsetting

julia> sum(eachrow(a))
ERROR:

messages.text: `sum.(eachcol(a))`?

elements.text: sum.(eachcol(a))

messages.text:
I will redirect this gripe to <@U687RKK0E> as:
```julia> sum([(a=1,b=2), (a=2, b=3)])
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::NamedTuple{(:a, :b), Tuple{Int64, Int64}}, ::NamedTuple{(:a, :b), Tuple{Int64, Int64}})```
:grin: (and one of the fundamental design principles in DataFrames.jl is to try to follow the rule of least surprise against Julia Base). However, you can do:
```julia> sum(Vector.(eachrow(a)))
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 6
 3```
and get the expected result, though probably it is easier and more efficient to do:
```julia> sum.(eachcol(a))
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 6
 3```
or
```julia> mapcols(sum, a)
1×2 DataFrame
 Row │ a      b     
     │ Int64  Int64 
─────┼──────────────
   1 │     6      3```

elements.text: I will redirect this gripe to
as:

julia> sum([(a=1,b=2), (a=2, b=3)])
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::NamedTuple{(:a, :b), Tuple{Int64, Int64}}, ::NamedTuple{(:a, :b), Tuple{Int64, Int64}})
(and one of the fundamental design principles in DataFrames.jl is to try to follow the rule of least surprise against Julia Base). However, you can do:

julia> sum(Vector.(eachrow(a)))
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 6
 3
and get the expected result, though probably it is easier and more efficient to do:

julia> sum.(eachcol(a))
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 6
 3
or

julia> mapcols(sum, a)
1×2 DataFrame
 Row │ a      b     
     │ Int64  Int64 
─────┼──────────────
   1 │     6      3

messages.text:
I'm not complaining about the library just to be clear - I use it all the time and really like it. Just one of those "wut" moments.

Usually I just map(x -> fn, eachcol(a)), didn't know about mapcols :slightly_smiling_face:.
